video.title: Microsoft Azure Fundamentals Certification Course (AZ-900) - Pass the exam in 3 hours!
video.description:
Learn about Microsoft Azure and pass the Azure Fundamentals exam! The Azure Fundamentals exam is an opportunity to prove knowledge of cloud concepts, core Azure services, Azure pricing, SLA, and lifecycle, and the fundamentals of cloud security, privacy, compliance, and trust. You will learn about all these things in this course.

✏️ Course developed by Andrew Brown of ExamPro. Check out the ExamPro YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2EsmbKnDNE7y1N3nZYCuGw
🔗 ExamPro Certification Training: https://www.exampro.co
🔗 LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/exam...
🐦 Twitter: https://twitter.com/andrewbrown
📷 Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/exampro.co/

topLevelComment.author: Albert Kwan
topLevelComment.text:
The Merriam-Webster dictionary defines premises as “a tract of land with buildings thereon,” whereas premise is “a proposition anecdotally supposed or proved as a basis of argument or interference.”

In other words, an IT data center is kept on premises, while the philosophers Rousseau and Machiavelli base their arguments around the state of nature as a premise. “Premises,” already a single noun, cannot be replaced by “premise,” and the two are quite different.

topLevelComment.author: Da Prophet Comedy TV
topLevelComment.text: UPDATE: This certification course now does not expire according to Microsoft updates. The Azure fundamentals certification is valid for life. In summary, all Microsoft Azure fundamental certs are valid for life.  Meanwhile, all other certs are valid for 1 year, renewable by taking a non proctored assessment starting from 6 months to its expiry. This is displayed and taken on your account. The assessment can be taken as many times as possible until you pass. If you fail to take the recertification assessment before the 12 months period elapses, your certification will expire and you'll need to sit in once again for a new proctored exam to achieve that certification.

topLevelComment.author: David Ribeiro
topLevelComment.text:
I just passed my exam (August 27, 2022) using this video.  Hope this helps others:

* My exam had 35 questions, but about 10 of them had 3 true/false statements inside each one of them. They say each true/false = 1 point, so the whole questions is worth 3 points total.

* There were 3 questions that presented me a screenshot from the management panel and asked me to click the icon where I could perform XXX in Azure.  You click the image and it highlights the icon you've clicked.

* People seem confused about the length of the test: the official sitting time is 60 minutes, of which 15 minutes are reserved for surveys and agreements, and 45 minutes are reserved for the questions. 
But IF you are doing it from home or office,  you should check-in 30 minutes prior to the scheduled time so you can go through the crappy PersonVUE process. So, in total:  
30min before the scheduled time(check-in *IF* remote) + 15min(surveys) + 45min(questions).

* Do not pay for the exam! Google "Microsoft Virtual Training Days", subscribe to a 2 days training from Microsoft (2.5 hours each, with no labs and no tests) and they'll give you a voucher for a az-900 exam for free. Check it out on the Training Day description page, inside the "After completing this training, you will be able to:" section it should say "Take the Microsoft Azure Fundamentals certification exam at no cost".  Also, AZ-900 is the only exam that have that option, so don't burn other kinds of "100% off" vouchers for it!  Save the voucher for other exams that don't have the virtual training days option.

* The questions are short and straightforward. Shouldn't take you more than 30 seconds each (a little longer for true/false packs).

*This is the only material I've used to study besides the 2 day training from Microsoft but I am already familiar with AWS, so some of the knowledge applied.   I would suggest some practice exams if you have no experience working on cloud. Try CloudConnect practice exams on Udemy. Their pratice exams are very close to the IRL exam.

*You get the full score report immediately after finishing the exame. Your certificate is available in about 15min and the credly badge shows up in about 20min.  Way better than AWS in this regard.

Please let me know if I forgot something.

Man, Azure sure is straightforward that I can remember the acronyms for the services.  I've been working on AWS and I still seem to struggle  with some of the minor tools and how they work and when you can use it.  Also I suppose going Azure makes more sense since 90% of IT work in a Windows environment, and if you want to do scripting Powershell is your best bet.

I've taken the Cloud Resume challenge and stopped at the CI/CD pipeline since I'm having a hard time getting Git to connect to my AWS S3 and so far I'm not finding "how" to do so, but I did find a video of someone who build a website in Azure using a bunch of front and back end tools.  My question is, how much will that cost me?  I see the guy get a quote for Blob (that's the file storage I believe) and it's 150.00 a month.

Think I'll give this cert a try.  It's fundamentals, but this video actually makes me feel confident I can pass this and help move up from Helpdesk/Support.

topLevelComment.author: Nikhil G
topLevelComment.text:
Hey if anyone is wondering how composite SLA is calculated here's how it is. 
So imagine you have one service at 99.95% and another at 99.99%. 
Now consider 99.95% as "99.95/100" and 99.99% as "99.99/100". 
When you multiply these fractions you will get 0.99940005 or 99.940005/100 which is the same as 99.94%

topLevelComment.author: HerrMutig
topLevelComment.text:
Just if anyone wonders how the math works at 2:49:09: 

Web App has 99,95 % (0.9995). 
SQL Database has 99.99% (0.9999)
Queue has 99.9% (0.999)

The Question is. How likely is it that both, the database and the queue, are not available.
This is answered by the following:

(1 - 0.9999) * (1 - 0.999) = 0.0000001.

The chance that both systems fail at the same time is 0.0000001. 

Therefore we also know now that at least one system is running with a percentage of 99.99999% (1 - 0.0000001 = 0.9999999)

=> 0.9995 * 0.9999999 = 0,9985006500249250125 (~0,9995)
or 99.95% * 99.99999% = ~99.85

I just went through this video, typed notes in Word, took a few free practice quizzes, and passed with plenty of room to spare! Got a certification with less than 1 day of studying thanks to this!
Thank you!

Edit: Stop asking for notes and practice questions. You are literally on the page for a video that explains everything you need, and you can use Google to find practice questions. If a 3-hour video and Googling something is too daunting, you won't make it in a senior IT role anyway.

replies.author: Isaiah Ryman
replies.text: It might not feel productive rewriting notes that somebody else has taken already, but when you take notes, you will process what your or learning more concisely. All ivy league schools recommend guided notes (fill in the blanks), but they highly discourage prewritten notes. And don't get me wrong, you do not need a college degree to get a job in programming if you get enough certifications, but ivy league schools have had a lot of trial and error to find the best way (generalizing) to learn for most people.

I put this to the test earlier this week.
12:45- signed up for an exam at 3:45 on the same day
12:45-2:45- watched the video at 1.5-2x speed, scribbling notes furiously
2:45-3:30- scanned the MS Learn training for things that showed up on the exam guide but weren't mentioned in the video
3:45- Took the exam
I passed with ~770, not confidently though. Go through the MS training and supplement with this video, particularly if you're coming in without a cloud background. There are a few things since the last update that aren't covered.

topLevelComment.author: Andriy Gavrylenko
topLevelComment.text: Your slide for "Evolution of Computing->Containers" is incorrect. Linux kernel is shared between all applications therefore, there is no "guest os" per se. There is only one docker daemon per host. Containers on the same host cannot run different OS as they all share the same kernel.

topLevelComment.author: James sam
topLevelComment.text:
I just passed my Microsoft Azure Fundamentals Certification Course this morning. Here is how I did it. First, I went through video, then purchased exam tests on exampro.co. I used other training environments, but that is how I do things. I like using material from different sources. It could be over kill, but what works for me may not work for you? I went through the practice test, I noticed it went from over 500 test question up to 700 using 12 test and one sheet of info. On a person note, I should have printed out the test review sheet (27 pages I believe) before going over the practice test.

The practice exams where very helpful, I do recommend (personal opinion) getting the practice test and review before taking the exam. It help me alot.


Good Luck!

replies.author: James sam
replies.text:
@ATC company I used 3 sources of training. First I watched this video as it was only 3 hours long. Then I used CBTNuggets and Cloud Guru. They both have the Azure AZ-900 training course and labs. But I do believe that I spend more time using Cloud Guru training and Labs more.  They both have practice test at the end of the training. I did go over theses practice test first. Then I used the practice test "exampro.co". This is how I did it. You don't have to use two different training environments. I did as each training course offered basically the same training material but just done in a different way.. So it added to my overall training experience. 

Good Luck

topLevelComment.author: Christopher Stamp
topLevelComment.text: I hate to nitpick grammar, but people may echo the writing and pronunciation of a few items which could hurt their credibility when repeating what has been presented.  The hyphenated word is "on-premises", not "on-premise".  Premise is only the singular form of premises when using it as a synonym for a concept, not the confines of land or a building which is always plural.  It's a common grammatical mistake and one I see over and over in presentations about architecture and the cloud.  Also, CapEx (capital expenditure) is pronounced like the "cap" in capital and OpEx (operating expense) is pronounced like "op" in operating.  They are accounting and finance concepts for how expenses are classified.

topLevelComment.author: Yuhe Chen
topLevelComment.text:
Thanks for sharing, Andrew. One thing that deserves clarification is the public subnet and private subnet concept.  
AWS VPC subnets can either be private or public. A subnet is public if it has an internet gateway (IGW) attached. AWS allows only one IGW per VPC and the public subnet allow resources deployed in them access to the internet. AWS creates a default VPC and subnets for each region. This default VPC has subnets for each region where the VPC resides, and any image (EC2 instance) deployed to this VPC will be assigned a public IP address and hence has internet connectivity. Azure VNet does not provide a default VNet and does not have private or public subnet as in AWS VPC. Resources connected to a VNet have access to the Internet, by default.
